Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Enabling Direct Microbial Biotransformation of Methane and Derived Methanol to Valuable Biochemicals and Biofuels by Yarrowia Lipolytica

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1360867
Trinh, Cong T.

Methane is abundant and comes from natural gas, coal, petroleum, and biogas of livestock; it is also one of the major and potent greenhouse gases. Methane is primarily used as a fuel for generating heat and electricity, and to produce methanol via the synthesis gas route, which is expensive to process as it is very energy intensive. Methane generated as a byproduct in a chemical process or as biogas of livestock is often either released or flared before being released to the environment. Therefore, effectively capturing and using methane can provide an abundant feedstock to produce valuable products and alleviate global warming. This EAGER proposal seeks to explore the untapped microbial biotransformation route to utilize methane and derived methanol for the synthesis of valuable biobased products. The proposed research will be transformative by achieving the direct microbial transformation of abundant methane and derived methanol to valuable biobased products at room temperature and ambient pressure with much less energy than conventional chemical transformation, and by simultaneously capturing methane to abate global warming. This project will also integrate the research into educational outreach activities that have significant impact on a diverse group of undergraduate and K-12 students at The University of Tennessee.

The goal of this EAGER proposal is to elucidate and activate the unique methane- and methanol-utilizing pathways of oleaginous yeasts (such as Yarrowia lipolytica) for biochemicals and biofuels synthesis. In this proposal, the PI team will use systems biology tools to address the following fundamental questions: 1) What genes are involved in the methanol-utilizing pathway of Y. lipolytica? and 2) Can Y. lipolytica utilize any of its diverse set of CYP450 monooxygenases to convert methane to methanol and enable growth on methane? Furthermore, the PI team will apply metabolic engineering and synthetic biology tools to harness the unique metabolism of Y. lipolytica to synthesize valuable biobased products from methane and methane-derived molecules. If successful, this project will shed light on unique methane- and methanol-utilizing pathways that are poorly understood in eukaryotes (e.g., Y. lipolytica) and pave the way for discovering other non-conventional yeasts that have both oleaginous and methanotrophic characteristics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Methane is abundant and comes from natural gas, coal, petroleum, and biogas of livestock; it is also one of the major and potent greenhouse gases. Methane is primarily used as a fuel for generating heat and electricity, and to produce methanol via the synthesis gas route, which is expensive to process. Currently, methane generated as a byproduct in a chemical process or as biogas of livestock is often either released or flared before being released to the environment. Therefore, effectively capturing and using methane can provide an abundant feedstock to produce valuable products and alleviate global warming. The long-term goal of the project is to harness the untapped microbial biotransformation route to utilize methane and derived methanol for the synthesis of valuable biobased products. This NSF-funded EAGER project aims to shed light on the poorly-understood metabolism of the oleaginous yeast Yarrowia lipolytica to assimilate methanol for novel biotransformation.

Genome mining revealed that Y. lipolytica possess native metabolism for methanol assimilation that comprises of the dissimilatory pathway for energy generation and the ribulose monophosphate assimilatory pathway to generate fueling precursors for biomass synthesis. Detailed characterization of cell growth, transcriptomics, enzymatic analysis, and metabolomics suggests that Y. lipolytica is capable of assimilating methanol as a carbon source albeit at lower efficiency than other methylotrophic yeasts such as Pichia pastoris. Like other alcohols, methanol is toxic to cell growth. A concentration of 1% (v/v) methanol shows an inhibitory growth effect on Y. lipolytica as well as other methylotrophic yeasts. Through adaptive evolution, novel mutants have been isolated to grow in at least at 3% (v/v) while the wildtype control could not grow. Further, the project also discovered that Y. lipolytica possesses native metabolism for direct synthesis of fatty acid methyl esters from carbohydrates and methanol. Taken all together, this EAGER project provides novel findings of unknown metabolism of Y. lipolytica for methanol assimilation and biotransformation, and helps lay out a foundation for further engineering Y. lipolytica as a manufacturing microbial platform to produce high-value biochemicals and biofuels from abundant methane and derived methanol substrates.

This 2-year EAGER project has provided training for 1 postdoctoral researcher, 2 graduate students, and 6 undergraduate students at The University of Tennessee Knoxville (UTK). Research findings on C1 metabolism of this project has been incorporated in the PI’s class “Elements of Synthetic Biology and Metabolic Engineering” that offers both undergraduate and graduate students at UTK. Further, this project helps contribute to the iGEM (International Genetically Engineered Machine) activity that the PI has been organizing and advising for a large pool of undergraduate students at UTK by exposing them to the growing fields of metabolic engineering and synthetic biology related to sustainable bioenergy and biofuels. This EAGER project also enables the PI to develop the 4-day Eastman workshop that provides hands-on experiences for 12th graders to work in the PI’s laboratory and inspire them to pursue higher education in STEM. To date, this EAGER project has generated 4 publications and several manuscripts currently in preparation.
